H0.text: Alternation of generation is the reason why the life cycle of plants is so complex.

H1.text: Metamorphosis is the reason the life cycle of plants is so complex.

H2.text: The pollination process explains why the life cycle of plants is so complex.

H3.text: Asexual reproduction is part of what makes the life cycle of plants so complex.

A4.text: Plant life cycles can be complex. Alternation of generations can take place in plants which are at once heteromorphic, sporophytic, oogametic, dioicous, heterosporic and dioecious, such as in a willow tree.

A5.text: In the process of double fertilization, two sperm nuclei from a pollen grain (the microgametophyte), rather than a single sperm, enter the archegonium of the megagametophyte; one fuses with the egg nucleus to form the zygote, the other fuses with two other nuclei of the gametophyte to form 'endosperm', which nourishes the developing embryo.

A6.text: In moss and hornwort sporophytes can photosynthesise, they require additional photosynthate from the gametophyte to sustain growth and spore development and depend on it for supply of water, mineral nutrients and nitrogen.

A7.text: In plants, both phases are multicellular: the haploid sexual phase – the gametophyte – alternates with a diploid asexual phase – the sporophyte.
